headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chair
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much, Gary. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining Cabot's fourth quarter and year-end earnings call. I do have members of the executive group with me today. And also, the forward-looking statements included in the morning's pr
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you very much, Gary. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining Cabot's fourth quarter and year-end earnings call. I do have members of the executive group with me today. And also, the forward-looking statements included in the morning's press release do apply to my comments. As you did see in the morning's press release, 2014 marked another successful year for Cabot Oil & Gas, as we generated top tier growth in production, reserves, earnings, cash flow, despite continued price challenges in the Marcellus, coupled with a deteriorating oil price environment during the second half of the year. 
Going over a couple of bullet points. Cabot generated record production volumes of 532 Bcfe, an increase of 29% over '13 levels and an increase of 32% when adjusting for the sale of the Mid-Continent and West Texas assets in 2013. This included record liquids production that increased 55% year-over-year when adjusting for the 2013 asset sales. 
Net income, excluding select item for the year, was $405 million or $0.97 per share, an increase of 36% over '13. And operating cash flows for the year were $1.2 billion, an increase of 21% year-over-year. This growth in earnings and cash flow was driven primarily by our strong production growth, combined with a 16% year-over-year decrease in unit cost. 
The company did take a non-cash after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of approximately $487 million related to the impairment of certain non-core properties, primarily in East Texas due to the significant decline in commodity prices and the decision not to pursue further activity in these legacy operating areas at this point in time. As a reminder, these assets were focus of the company prior to our development of the Marcellus to Eagle Ford and have not seen any meaningful levels of drilling activity since 2010. So there was no impact to the company's reserve report. 
I would also like to highlight that during the year, we purchased 4.3 million shares of our common stock and added approximately 40,000 net acres in our Eagle Ford position, all while we maintained a strong balance sheet with conservative leverage, metrics and over $1.3 billion of available borrowing capacity under our current facility at year end. 
On our proved reserves, in addition to this strong operational and financial performance during the year, we also generated significant growth in the year-end proved reserves, which increased 36% to over 4 point -- excuse me, 7.4 Tcfe. Cabot's all sourced finding and development cost for the year was $0.71 for Mcfe. This is particularly impressive given that over 43% of our 2014 capital was allocated to our oil properties in Eagle Ford that by nature are more capital intensive. Excluding the purchase of reserves in play associated with our Eagle Ford acquisition last year, the total company finding and development cost was $0.65 per Mcfe. 
In the Marcellus, our all sources finding development cost was $0.43 per Mcf, highlighting the capital efficiency of our wells in the Northeast PA. Obviously, one of the components is that our wells in this area do deliver very strong EURs. The Cabot's average EUR for the 2014 program on proved developed wells was over 18 Bcf, up from the 16.9 Bcf for our '13 program. As a result of our continued performance improvements, we have also increased our reserve bookings on locations in the Marcellus from an EUR of 10 Bcf to 11 Bcf per well. Our proved developed percentage increased from 59% in '13 to 61% in '14, highlighting our fairly conservative philosophy regarding our reserve bookings. For example, we booked a modest 0.7 offset pad location for each of our proved developed wells in the Marcellus at year-end. Our year-end reserves were 60 -- excuse me, 96% natural gas, down from the 97% in '13, which was driven by 100% increase in our liquids reserve base. Approximately 89% of our proved reserves are located in the Marcellus shale. 
I would also like to highlight that the Department of Environmental Protection released the production data for the second half of 2014 this week. And once again, Cabot dominated the list with the top 16 wells in the stake. 
Now let's move to our '15 program. While our '14 operational performance are in the rearview mirror, the results do highlight Cabot's ability to deliver strong results in a challenged price environment. However, we are immune to the market conditions the entire industry is currently facing. On our third quarter earnings call in October of last year, I laid out the company's initial 2015 program, which was predicated on realized natural gas price and oil prices of $2.80 and $88, respectively. As you all are aware, the operating environment the industry is facing has changed drastically since our call less than 4 months ago. While much of the focus over the last few months has been on the declining oil price, we have also experienced a fairly meaningful decline in the natural gas prices, including the regional index prices in Appalachia [indiscernible] what we are seeing in the major U.S. oil basis, Cabot and its peers have done an excellent job of finding an abundant supply of resources in the Marcellus. And as a result, supply-demand balance is currently at a sink. Until we see the rebalancing of the market, which reduced activity -- with the reduced activity, which I think is currently underway, I believe the industry will continue to see pricing pressures on both oil and gas. As you will recall, in the fourth quarter of last year, we saw a significant increase in natural gas supply on the 3 major pipes in our area, which included a 15% sequential increase in Cabot's volume in anticipation of winter. However, winter demand did not materialize as we all would have expected. And as a result, we have seen the local interface in January and February set at levels significantly  lower than our initial forecast. 
In response to this lower commodity price environment, we have adjusted our 2015 program with a focus on protecting the balance sheet and maximizing our return on investment while still managing our growth profile. Despite the change in our absolute levels of activity in 2015, our strategy remains unchanged. A focus on aligning our capital spending to be primarily funded by operating cash flows, focus our drilling efforts on maintaining our acreage position and optimizing operating efficiencies and the retention of our high-quality employee base. This strategy has positioned us a favorably leading into this commodity cycle. And we believe this strategy will allow us to exit the cycle extremely well-positioned. 
Company updated capital budget for 2015 is $900 million, which is a 42% decrease compared to our initial budget. Approximately 80% of the program will be directed towards drilling and completion activity, with 60% allocated to the Marcellus and 40% allocated to the Eagle Ford. 
In the Marcellus, we are currently operating 5 rigs with plans to decrease to 3 rigs by the end of the second quarter. Based on this level of activity, we expect to drill approximately 70 net wells and place 65 to 70 wells on production during the year. Given the backlog of wells we carried into 2015 and our anticipated level of activity during the year, we expect to exit the year with approximately 45 wells in the queue for 2016. Despite drilling longer laterals in '15, we expect well cost average between $6 million and $6.5 million as a result of operating efficiencies and the service cost reductions that we have received to date. However, as we are all aware, this is a dynamic market and our expectation is that as commodity prices remain depressed for a sustained period of time and the level of activity industrywide continues to decline, we will likely see a further reduction in cost. 
In the Eagle Ford, we are currently operating 3 rigs with plans to decrease to 1 rig by the end of the second quarter. Given where oil prices are currently, our focus is solely on lease maintenance and meeting all drilling obligations. Based on our planned rig count for the year, we expect to drill approximately 45 net wells and place 40 to 45 wells on production during the year. Again, given our backlog of wells that we carried into '15, our anticipated level of activity during the year, we expect to exit '15 with approximately 20 wells teed up ready for 2016. Similar to the Marcellus, we expect well cost for the year to average between $6 million and $6.5 million with an opportunity for further cost reductions as we move through the year. 
We remain excited about what we have seen so far in our 90,000-acre net position, which is all contiguous. However, in light of the current price environment, we believe the prudent decision is to maintain all of the acreage and wait until sustained recovery prices before we start accelerating activities in the future. Based on this updated operating program, we have adjusted our production guidance range for the year to 10% to 18%, which includes 50% to 60% growth in liquids production. This guidance range assumes a modest level of fulfillment to the Marcellus in anticipation of maintenance and high line pressures at certain points during the year. Additionally, we have also included of price-related curtailments in this guidance to account for those periods where price simply does not meet our threshold. Obviously, the natural question would be how much and what price we would take these actions. For competitive reasons, we will not disclose specifics. But I will say that our production profile for the year assumes entire volumes in the first quarter with a reduction in the second and third quarters and increasing again in the fourth quarter. The realized commodity prices used in this updated budget to make our $900 million program were $0.45 per Mcf, $2.45 for our natural gas and $55 per barrel for oil. This includes the impact of our natural gas hedges, which covers about 28% of our natural gas volumes at the midpoint of our updated guidance range. Also, for the full year, approximately 50% of our sales, gas sales, are price at 3 major indices in Northeast PA, which is Tennessee, Leidy and Millennium. Under these assumptions, our operating program would result in a very small level of ad spend, allowing us to maintain the same financial strength we demonstrated prior to this down cycle while still providing double-digit growth and generating returns. Some of you may find -- or may have questions about 2016, given our reduced level of activity this first year. First, let me say that our internal model shows continued growth in 2016 with the level of growth dependent upon factors that we'll certainly understand better as 2015 progresses. However, once you factor how commodity price environment evolves throughout 2015, we do anticipate similar operational and supply reductions by other operators in Northeast PA and reaction to the current prices and our expectation is that this will ultimately result in a rationalization of the supply and demand dynamics in our area. Given the expectation for our tapering of supply growth, coupled with new takeaway capacities in the Northeast, that's Leidy Southeast expansion and the [indiscernible] Eastside expansion that's coming online in the second half of the year, we will remain flexible with our program if the market wants us to make changes. Given the productivity and the low capital intensity of our wells in the Marcellus, we are well-positioned to adjust our operations in short order. As a reminder, we grew to our current production levels by never operating more than 6 rigs in the Marcellus. And given the anticipated backlog of 65 wells companywide at year-end 2015, we do have plenty of optionality to accelerate completions in the second half of the year as we see fit. As I mentioned earlier, our plan is to maintain our high quality employee base and we believe that positions us very well in the light -- in the event of a quick recovery. 
Another key factor that will drive '16 growth and enhance program returns will be the anticipated in-service of Constitution Pipeline, which is currently planned for the second half of 2016. Cabot has 500 million a day of capacity on this pipeline. So the timing of when this pipeline comes online will obviously have an impact on 2016 production levels. As a quick update on Constitution, there were a few significant accomplishments at the end of last year that bear repeating. As you are aware, on December 2, 2014, the FERC issued a certificate of public convenience and necessity, approving the Constitution Pipeline. In addition, on December 24, the New York BBC issued a formal notice of complete application regarding the final permits necessary from New York. We're currently awaiting the conclusion of the New York state public comment period, which is scheduled on February 27, 2015. Moving forward, we are hopeful to receive our final permits from New York during the second quarter and immediately file for the implementation and construction plan with the FERC with construction beginning this summer. 
So in summary, I've covered many topics. We are well-positioned to adapt and succeed in this price environment. I think it's clear, our asset base and our disciplined focus itself to allowing us to generate returns at these price levels that maybe many other operators will not -- or may not experience. And despite the current market conditions, we remain committed to delivering long-term shareholder value and certainly maintaining our strong balance sheet. Gary, with those comments, I'll turn it back over to you to queue up some questions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, a couple of things, if I may. First of all, on Constitution. Just to be clear, so what has been -- what does [indiscernible] moving forward with construction? I'd say -- I guess the right way the New York is still the bottleneck. But in terms of all
componenttext: Dan, a couple of things, if I may. First of all, on Constitution. Just to be clear, so what has been -- what does [indiscernible] moving forward with construction? I'd say -- I guess the right way the New York is still the bottleneck. But in terms of all the other preparations, can you actually start now? Or are you still waiting -- can you not start until everything is lined up? I'm just trying to understand what that might be.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question and a question that's obviously in a lot of people's mind. I'll make a brief comment to turn it over to Jeff for any add specific color. But we have submitted all the permits. We submitted our original permits back in August of '13. There ha
componenttext: Good question and a question that's obviously in a lot of people's mind. I'll make a brief comment to turn it over to Jeff for any add specific color. But we have submitted all the permits. We submitted our original permits back in August of '13. There has been significant dialogue between Williams, the operator of the pipeline, not only the FERC but also the New York DEC. The protocol in moving through this process is that the DEC has made the determination as I mentioned on the 24th of December that we have fulfilled our obligation to give them all of the information they need to deem the project complete. With that though, there comes a public comment period. And that public comment period, we are in this period of time and it ends at the end of this month. Subsequent to that, the expectation is with no new issues that would have -- that have not come up over the last couple of years, that the New York DEC will grant a final permit. And then that will allow us to make the application to FERC to begin construction.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Doug, just to add a few points of that. The application process in New York and Pennsylvania for that matter over course we're finished in Pennsylvania, has been pretty much what we expected as a little bit longer than anticipated, but the process fo
componenttext: Yes. Doug, just to add a few points of that. The application process in New York and Pennsylvania for that matter over course we're finished in Pennsylvania, has been pretty much what we expected as a little bit longer than anticipated, but the process for this. And by getting the notice of complete application, it does signal that the New York DEC has all the information they need to issue the final permits. And the process we're in now is standard and operating procedure, where public comments are welcome based on the action that New York DEC took. In terms of getting construction started, Williams will file an implementation plan with FERC, probably next month. And then an implementation plan will include permits from all the agencies involved, including ones that FERC issued. And it will be complemented with the final permit from the New York once that's issued. When FERC gives that final determination, they'll issue a notice to proceed with construction. At that point, construction can begin. So it allows moving pieces but you really cannot dig dirt until all the pieces are all in place.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick follow-ups. I guess on some numbers, if I may. First, can you quantify the curtailments that you've assumed in your guidance for the current year? And finally, any scale of anticipated cost reduction from this point forward over and above wha
componenttext: Just 2 quick follow-ups. I guess on some numbers, if I may. First, can you quantify the curtailments that you've assumed in your guidance for the current year? And finally, any scale of anticipated cost reduction from this point forward over and above what you already achieved in terms of service cost? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the curtailments, we will not be exactly specific. But I can say that if, in fact, all of the available production would move, we would certainly approach the lower end of our previous guidance. And in regard to cost, again, we have seen the cost
componenttext: Okay. On the curtailments, we will not be exactly specific. But I can say that if, in fact, all of the available production would move, we would certainly approach the lower end of our previous guidance. And in regard to cost, again, we have seen the cost roll off no different than the other operators that have made a release. And we anticipate though also, as you continue to see service or programs lay down rigs, there's going to be a natural tendency to continue to keep equipment and people teed up and busy through the service sector. And we can see additional service cost reductions throughout the year.

componenttext: On the completion side, of course, one thing we'll continue to look at is the optimum spacing between frac intervals and [indiscernible] 200 feet under the lateral 50-foot spacing. Again, all these we're looking at optimizing our landing point to. So again, we're continuing to tweak the and then look for ways to improve.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the other one I have is just on the well cost reduction that you're seeing so far, what percentage of that is just your own optimization versus third-party service declines?
componenttext: And the other one I have is just on the well cost reduction that you're seeing so far, what percentage of that is just your own optimization versus third-party service declines?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have specific numbers on the third-party service declines. Again, you're seeing it through again the releases that have occurred to date out there. But rig cost coming down and pumping services coming down are the major components that the operat
componenttext: Well, we have specific numbers on the third-party service declines. Again, you're seeing it through again the releases that have occurred to date out there. But rig cost coming down and pumping services coming down are the major components that the operational efficiencies are -- it's kind of an ongoing effort in our program. And we continue to try to do those things that would allow us to create more efficiencies, either by enhancements to the amount of production or EURs that we can recognize or tweaking the components of a completion for the most part or landing points that will allow us to gain time and or frac efficiencies with either spacing considerations or the amount of proppant pump, those common things that we all look at. So I don't have a specific breakdown though between the components of service cost reductions and operational efficiencies. The majority of that has occurred most recently has been from the service side.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last one, if I may. Just wanted to get -- with the updated guidance now, looking spent fairly close to cash flow and preserve that balance sheet. Are you starting to see opportunities in and around your core areas to expand your positions from some other
componenttext: Last one, if I may. Just wanted to get -- with the updated guidance now, looking spent fairly close to cash flow and preserve that balance sheet. Are you starting to see opportunities in and around your core areas to expand your positions from some other folks that are maybe a little bit more stretched?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: In these environments where commodity price fall off so rapidly, typically there's a level between the time when that falloff occurs and the M&A activity. And I think we're in that period right now. The expectation by those that have assets and that might
componenttext: In these environments where commodity price fall off so rapidly, typically there's a level between the time when that falloff occurs and the M&A activity. And I think we're in that period right now. The expectation by those that have assets and that might have some stress points are -- they're going to hold as long as they possibly can in hopes of a quick bounce off the bottom. But I can say from a strategic standpoint, we do look at this period of time as an opportunity. And if we see the bolt-on, as you referring to, fit what our long-term plan is because we are balancing this market for the long-term and not just the short term, we'll take advantage of it. And our balance sheet, certainly, allows us. At the end of the year, as we mentioned, we had $1.3 billion of available capacity to utilize. So we're in good shape to take advantage of what opportunities come along.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Then you generally in the past have spoken to building a backlog of wells in anticipation of Constitution coming online. How much of your CapEx production here is a function of greater flexibility, given the lack of clarity on the Constitution instead of
componenttext: Then you generally in the past have spoken to building a backlog of wells in anticipation of Constitution coming online. How much of your CapEx production here is a function of greater flexibility, given the lack of clarity on the Constitution instead of startup time? Has there been any strategic change in which you would plan to fully supply Constitution with wells yet to come online versus wells contributing to the oversupply today of the local market?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have reacted with our capital program to today based on commodity price. We bought that the differentials and we all realized the loss of $45, $50 on a per barrel. And we have reacted with a reduction in our activity, i.e. capital that translates
componenttext: Well, we have reacted with our capital program to today based on commodity price. We bought that the differentials and we all realized the loss of $45, $50 on a per barrel. And we have reacted with a reduction in our activity, i.e. capital that translates into the number of wells drilled and completed, just purely based on that commodity price assumptions and maintaining our cash flow neutral program. And looking at Constitution and looking at, as I mentioned, the queue that we have built up of 40, 45 wells that we'll have at the end of 2015, we are going to be in good shape to be able to build our volumes into the expected commissioning date of '15. We continue to see efficiencies as we've reported from our '13 program to our '14 program. We expect continued efficiency gains in our '15 program, which I think is going to translate into maybe higher IPs and higher EURs, which would allow for a more rapid increase in the amount deliverability leading up to Constitution. I think again, a point to illustrate is the fact that in one of the premier gas fields in the entire world and an area that's growing probably faster than any other place that I'm aware of in the world is the County area in Pennsylvania. And all of the Marcellus, Cabot had the top 16 wells in the entire field. So I think that speaks volumes on our ability to be able to grow into the additional 500 million a day that is our volumes on Constitution in a fairly quick order and I might add without a lot of capital intensity.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then separately, you built up your Eagle Ford commensurate with your growth in the Marcellus over the last few years. So the down cycle in those oil and natural gas prices provide an opportunity to materially shift your exposure -- to around these are
componenttext: And then separately, you built up your Eagle Ford commensurate with your growth in the Marcellus over the last few years. So the down cycle in those oil and natural gas prices provide an opportunity to materially shift your exposure -- to around these areas? Or are you committed to the balance parameter in the portfolio?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I like the 60-40 balance we have in the Eagle Ford and the Marcellus.
componenttext: I like the 60-40 balance we have in the Eagle Ford and the Marcellus.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Exactly what you think about the production percentages or the reserves percentages, do you see an opportunity for larger scale M&A here to move around your core areas and waiting of your core areas? Or should we expect we come out of that have a similar
componenttext: Exactly what you think about the production percentages or the reserves percentages, do you see an opportunity for larger scale M&A here to move around your core areas and waiting of your core areas? Or should we expect we come out of that have a similar waiting to the Eagle Ford, Marcellus and nothing else?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's a good question also, because again, a lot of opportunity occurs to those that have a strong balance sheet and optionality in a down market. And we're certainly one of those companies. We don't have anything on the books, Brian. But again, to t
componenttext: And that's a good question also, because again, a lot of opportunity occurs to those that have a strong balance sheet and optionality in a down market. And we're certainly one of those companies. We don't have anything on the books, Brian. But again, to think about our long-term runway and to position us to take advantage of uptick in the oil market, for example, I think it is prudent for us to look at what type of area we might want to be in the long-term and how we might want to position and how we create that position. But again, as being the singular focus, our strong need at this particular period of time, it is not that. But certainly, it's an idea that we kick around, and we look at and we build out a base on to be able to understand the markets out there in the longer-term. So if we move around the balance of commodity, i.e. more oil versus our 60 -- our 96% gas versus 4% oil, it will be a long-term view and we'll take advantage of it. And I think we could do something in the future.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jeffrey, actually of course, the pipe is on location and the construction have gone out and we have contractors waiting on others to proceed. Everything is se tup and staged and ready to go, waiting on the final permits. That said, there are a few o
componenttext: Okay, Jeffrey, actually of course, the pipe is on location and the construction have gone out and we have contractors waiting on others to proceed. Everything is se tup and staged and ready to go, waiting on the final permits. That said, there are a few operating windows that have to be considered, such as streams crossings and clearing and that sort of thing. But basically regardless of when you start and through the windows of construction, you're talking about less than a year to get everything in place, tested and operating.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very useful. Dan, based on product guidance, it looks like you've reduced your 2015 wells drilled by a greater percentage of the Marcellus of the Eagle Ford. Can you add a little more color on that? And the reason why I'm asking is because you rece
componenttext: That's very useful. Dan, based on product guidance, it looks like you've reduced your 2015 wells drilled by a greater percentage of the Marcellus of the Eagle Ford. Can you add a little more color on that? And the reason why I'm asking is because you recently said that Marcellus returns at $2 per 1 million Btu [ph] are better than the Eagle Ford returns at $70 per barrel. So I thought some color might be useful.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we won't have some new acreage that we acquired in Eagle Ford. And that new acreage we acquired in the Eagle Ford had near-term lease expirations that required drilling activity. And so our balance of capital we're bringing it down to kind of our ca
componenttext: Well, we won't have some new acreage that we acquired in Eagle Ford. And that new acreage we acquired in the Eagle Ford had near-term lease expirations that required drilling activity. And so our balance of capital we're bringing it down to kind of our cash flow level just dictated, based on the acreage capture in the Eagle Ford how much activity we are going to have in that particular area. And in regard to where that places our -- our activity in the Marcellus, we have ample supply to sell into the market that would give us a growth profile greater than what we have represented in our guidance. However, every incremental amount of gas that we would produce in the Marcellus goes into the indices that are the most challenged right now. So to grow into that with additional drilling, even though we are, yes, recognizing very good returns, it still blows down to the balancing act between our cash flow and the amount of activity that's necessary for our maintenance program. So that's the balance that we see short-term being our '15 program.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that makes great sense. If I could make less quick one in. You said previously you intended to target investment grade average metrics in 2015. And I'm wondering if your revised CapEx is guided by this goal? And does it primary balance sheet metric in the future of commodity volatility in 2015?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeffrey, yes, that's still a goal. Again, Dan hit on the key points of what we did related to the capital. But we've got a strategy around our capital modeling, both in good times and in bad that we want to be right on top of or very near the anticipated
componenttext: Jeffrey, yes, that's still a goal. Again, Dan hit on the key points of what we did related to the capital. But we've got a strategy around our capital modeling, both in good times and in bad that we want to be right on top of or very near the anticipated cash flow. And as a result of that, we have built a company that is very close to investment grade. Clearly, from a debt-to-EBITDA perspective, that has been kind of a -- kind of those limits in terms of investment grade metrics simply because of the underlying cash flow. But the overall leverage won't change as we alluded to in our opening comments.

Not only is the Constitution teed up for the middle of '16 at half of Bcf a day, I'll let Jeff go into the order of additional projects we have and he might also just touch on what we have at the end of this year, too.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll try to keep it fairly larger numbers. So we have a number of projects that 20,000 a day here and 25,000 a day there that do add up. But probably in the near term, we have the East expansion that's coming on later in '15 and Cabot has 50,000 acr
componenttext: Sure. I'll try to keep it fairly larger numbers. So we have a number of projects that 20,000 a day here and 25,000 a day there that do add up. But probably in the near term, we have the East expansion that's coming on later in '15 and Cabot has 50,000 acreage position there. The Leidy Southeast project comes on December of '15. And we have some additional long-term market associated with that. Probably, the -- I'll mentioned one other, the project coming along in October '17. We have 100,000 a day position on that and that will connect -- take off the railway system. But the big project is the 850 million a day coming on in September 2017. That's Williams project that Atlantic Sunrise. And that's a new 30-inch pipe connected in the heart of our production area. And as we mentioned late last year, the capacity that 150,000 a day, 100% of those volumes are committed for sales. We announced the point single term note long-term sale of 350,000 a day to -- for 20 years. And we announced the 0.5 Bcf a day to [indiscernible] for 500,000 a day. So that's certainly going to take us in 2017 with a  good program, good plan and currently working on the next projects.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Before you spoke about the volumes in the Marcellus ticking down in 2Q and 3Q, just if you can provide color if that's managing to expectations of demand or if there's something else going on there?
componenttext: Before you spoke about the volumes in the Marcellus ticking down in 2Q and 3Q, just if you can provide color if that's managing to expectations of demand or if there's something else going on there?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the 2 things. We are looking at just the system as a whole, depending on what type of inflection we get with the supply side and the propensity of gas being curtailed, if, in fact, the indices fall off or stay too low. I think selling into like a low
componenttext: Yes, the 2 things. We are looking at just the system as a whole, depending on what type of inflection we get with the supply side and the propensity of gas being curtailed, if, in fact, the indices fall off or stay too low. I think selling into like a low cost market is or a low value market is going to be rationalized a little bit. But what occurs during the shoulder months would be some pressure up on the pipelines. And during that period of time, it can back gas off the market, even though there has been a number of projects to compress and to mitigate the line pressures in the past. So that is 1 component to the lower volumes that I've alluded to in the second and third quarter. The other is just putting a soft spot in our guidance for low gas prices. If we see low gas prices, we're just not going to give our gas away and we would take gas off the market. So that's the reason -- nothing operational except for the midstream part of the operation to give us that well.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

componenttext: Yes. So overall, these plans are in that 300 million a day plus range. componenttext: Okay, that would be high as well. Okay, got it. And then service cost. I guess what we've read from other operators in Appalachia is that unlike some of the oil-producing basins, there wasn't really excess margins that service companies were generating last year. So the view is that given 2015 dynamics, they don't have that much room to give to where the types of cost inflation we're seeing from the oil basins 20%, 25% expected Q4 to Q4 may not be realized. I think you did say the 25% is possible. But what would you say about that context provided by other Appalachian operators?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just make a statement about our own experience. And each service provider can be a little bit unique on what their ultimate goal is. Some would prefer to capture margin and some would prefer to keep their equipment and their personnel busy a
componenttext: Well, I would just make a statement about our own experience. And each service provider can be a little bit unique on what their ultimate goal is. Some would prefer to capture margin and some would prefer to keep their equipment and their personnel busy and they would sacrifice margin. So our operation is a very consolidated acreage position. We have a very efficient operation from the standpoint of the service providers. And I'll talk about [indiscernible] as being the highest percentage of any one competed well rig. But we move up from 1 location to the other and everything is set up and ready to go. So they keep their equipment and personnel running 24/7 and very efficient. And I think that is attractive to them. But you look at the reduction that we've referenced already. And we go from, say, a $7 million well to a $6 million to $6.5 million well. We're already seeing those incremental reductions in service cost. And again, whatever -- the rest of the market does is -- and what service cost realizations they see is going to be all unique and individual. But we are seeing fairly significant cost reductions.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful.  And can we just review again the trajectory of production for the year? So are you expecting production to be up in the first quarter? headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015

componenttext: Well, I think you summed it up on what our expectation is through the year. And we've given the 50% to 60% expected growth in the liquids for the year. Liquids production or the production profile in the South region is going to be more consistent than the production profile that we guided and put into our program in the North region. We just have -- we have more flexibility on swing volumes in the North region and on the Marcellus area than we do in the South region. So I guess at high-level summary, Joe, we kind of maintain and grow a little bit of our production year-over-year in the South region. And in the North region, higher first quarter, just like you through the year, the second and third quarter down and then increasing again in the fourth.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. Possibly a couple of reasons. One would be that we're restricted right now. And the reason why we have differentials is because of the volumes of gas moving into the 3 pipes up there. In the future, we would expect in the pipes that Jeff has be
componenttext:
Well, yes. Possibly a couple of reasons. One would be that we're restricted right now. And the reason why we have differentials is because of the volumes of gas moving into the 3 pipes up there. In the future, we would expect in the pipes that Jeff has been talking about that are on the drawing board and
moving forward and have expected commissioning dates with those pipes and allowing additional additional gas or gas to get out of that particular area and also those 3 pipes in particular is going to allow, certainly, different dynamics going forward than we are experiencing today. I can't predict exactly what the impact is going to be on supply side or the demand side, let's say, at the end of 2017. But I can say that we are going to have a significant level of additional volumes of our gas that would be seeking and priced in different markets than we are experiencing today. So operationally, Marshall, you could still have operators and pressures on pipes based on the amount of volume running through them. But I think the opportunity to -- and the flexibility that additional pipes is going to afford us in the future is going to be fairly significant.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So with Constitution coming on in the second half of next year, maybe there could be some seasonality between Q1 and Q2, but you would expect it once cost should come online?
componenttext: So with Constitution coming on in the second half of next year, maybe there could be some seasonality between Q1 and Q2, but you would expect it once cost should come online?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say you would probably see, since there's not the volumes of gas that have access to their core system, I would say that you would probably, on those particular volumes, I would think that you probably would not see as much of the seasona
componenttext: Yes. And I would say you would probably see, since there's not the volumes of gas that have access to their core system, I would say that you would probably, on those particular volumes, I would think that you probably would not see as much of the seasonality effects on that pipe as you -- as we experienced today on the 3 pipes, Tennessee, the Leidy and the Millennium with the volumes of gas that is trying to force their way into those pipes today.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question for me. On Constitution, I wanted to clarify and hopefully get a little bit more color on how you're thinking about those volumes in 2016 and beyond. Is the plan to potentially shift some of your existing production away from Leidy a
componenttext: Just a quick question for me. On Constitution, I wanted to clarify and hopefully get a little bit more color on how you're thinking about those volumes in 2016 and beyond. Is the plan to potentially shift some of your existing production away from Leidy and Tennessee into that pipe and therefore improve margin? Or are you planning on completing new wells to grow production into 2016?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, both are really good questions. Both are good questions. The indices, the price received in the 3-pipe area that all of the operators are exposed to right now up in that 6-county area is somewhat of a determining factor on whether or not we relieve t
componenttext: Yes, both are really good questions. Both are good questions. The indices, the price received in the 3-pipe area that all of the operators are exposed to right now up in that 6-county area is somewhat of a determining factor on whether or not we relieve the amount of gas that is on those 3 pipes by just a flat cell transfer of 0.5 Bcf. Actually, the 650 million a day because Southwest is part of that Constitution Pipeline being 650 million a day capacity. Or would it be an incremental volume that would flow into the pipe. And that decision, Matt, is going to be a combination of price point and the ability to diverse the amount of gas that is flowing into those of 3 pipes with some of the new pipes that are coming online, i.e. Leidy, Southeast, the impact on those 3 pipes, the TECO expansion and some of the other smaller projects that Jeff mentioned. So I can say this though. But from a planning standpoint, we're going to be prepared to have incremental volumes going into the Constitution Pipeline. But we're also going to remain focused on the best returns and price rationalization if the market has not done that for us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And my second follow-up, as you talked about previously, your Eagle Ford assets continue to improve in terms of the breakeven economics, given the enhanced completions you've put into place. Could you provide some color as to how you're thinking ab
componenttext: Great. And my second follow-up, as you talked about previously, your Eagle Ford assets continue to improve in terms of the breakeven economics, given the enhanced completions you've put into place. Could you provide some color as to how you're thinking about potentially re-accelerating that program in the out years? And potentially, what commodity price you need to see at this point, given service cost to average back to that market?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, our balanced focus, Matt, has been on -- let's look at the amount of cash flow we're generating. And the amount of cash flow we generate is going to kind of dictate what we do with our capital program. So it would go hand-in-hand. We do have
componenttext: Well, again, our balanced focus, Matt, has been on -- let's look at the amount of cash flow we're generating. And the amount of cash flow we generate is going to kind of dictate what we do with our capital program. So it would go hand-in-hand. We do have a higher price point, better cash flow will roll into consideration for adding rigs, whether it be in the Marcellus or the Eagle Ford. It is our objective though in the Eagle Ford to maintain all the acreage we have out there. We like what we're seeing. We like what the group is doing now. And we like the returns that we can get. But at $55, we're not impressed with the returns at $55. At $60, $65, certainly it has a return profile that starts getting attractive again.

componenttext: Bob, it's Scott Schroeder. It has been alluded to based on question in terms of the repurchase. Clearly for 2015, the question you post isn't on the table in light of how far we had to our capital program and we're still not quite exact equal with cash flow. But at the end of the day, we're balancing that decision in different times. We're looking at the disconnect between the underlying value we see in the shares and what the market at any one moment is giving for our shares in the marketplace. We've seen those disconnects over the last couple of years. And that's why between, probably -- between '13 and '14 we bought in just under 10 million shares on that kind of dynamic.

What's the time frame from these potential projects and volumes and the economics, I guess, versus your selling gas directly on the pipeline to somebody, I mean? It sounds interesting.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Bob, some of the projects that are being proposed have actually -- gosh, from an excess of 20 I have on my desk that we are interested in, some more than others, some that we have very good access to, some that maybe are more difficult to get, and I'm
componenttext: So Bob, some of the projects that are being proposed have actually -- gosh, from an excess of 20 I have on my desk that we are interested in, some more than others, some that we have very good access to, some that maybe are more difficult to get, and I'm talking about transportation path. But there's a lot of projects planned in the Atlantic -- mid-Atlantic states. And in Pennsylvania, there's been a push to in conjunction with the ISO in that area to build some power generation and feed it with local supply. So we're looking at projects that are close by at Susquehanna County or have direct routes, pipeline routes, that we can reach these projects. I think the -- some of the planners of these -- and we did mention the Panda project. They probably have 4 or 5 other projects that are well along the way in terms of planning locations and permitting and financing and so forth. Most of these guys get their power deal done first, in other words, access to the grid. And then they come to gas suppliers. And they have their wish list and we have our wish list and we try to work through those and come to terms. There's 4 or 5 [ph] power generators off the system that we're working with as well. And there are some off Tennessee system and there are some of the Leidy system. This is going to be a profit that goes on probably in the next 5 to 10 years, even, just a lot of opportunity for power generation with natural gas with coal retirements and with coal switching and oil switching. It's a piece of the demand puzzle and it's very active and very dynamic. And we're situated in the Northeast corner. We're probably the closest supplier to market there is. And so we're comfortable with these kinds of markets. And we're probably announcing, if we are to be successful in the next year or 2 on some of these projects.

componenttext: Okay. Well, I think at some point, Williams I think they had their call yesterday. I think they had some questions on this as well. There's lots of major pipelines through the state of New York, a lot of gas pipeline but also power cord, lots of water lines and so on and so forth. This is relatively simple, 124-mile pipeline through rural New York. It's got its environmental challenges with all pipelines through I think New York. DEC has run very careful and thorough examination of the route and the issues and listening to the concerns of centers. They're going back with this year. And at the end of the day, we have to get a permit that lets this pipeline be built in the time frame that we've illustrated so far.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chair
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much, Gary. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining Cabot's fourth quarter and year end earnings call. I do have members of the executive group with me today. And also, the forward-looking statements included in the morning's pr
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you very much, Gary. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining Cabot's fourth quarter and year end earnings call. I do have members of the executive group with me today. And also, the forward-looking statements included in the morning's press release do apply to my comments. As you did see in the morning's press release, 2014 marked another successful year for Cabot Oil & Gas, as we generated top tier growth in production, reserves, earnings, cash flow, despite continued price challenges in the Marcellus, coupled with a deteriorating oil price environment during the second half of the year. 
Going over a couple of bullet points. Cabot generated record production volumes of 532 Bcfe, an increase of 29% over '13 levels and an increase of 32% when adjusting for the sale of the Mid-Continent and West Texas assets in 2013. This included record liquids production that increased 55% year-over-year when adjusting for the 2013 asset sales. 
Net income, excluding select item for the year, was $405 million or $0.97 per share, an increase of 36% over '13. And operating cash flows for the year were $1.2 billion, an increase of 21% year-over-year. This growth in earnings and cash flow was driven primarily by our strong production growth, combined with a 16% year-over-year decrease in unit cost. 
The company did take a non-cash after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of approximately $487 million related to the impairment of certain non-core properties, primarily in East Texas due to the significant decline in commodity prices and the decision not to pursue further activity in these legacy operating areas at this point in time. As a reminder, these assets were the focus of the company prior to our development of the Marcellus and Eagle Ford and have not seen any meaningful levels of drilling activity since 2010. So there was no impact to the company's reserve report. 
I would also like to highlight that during the year we purchased 4.3 million shares of our common stock and added approximately 40,000 net acres in our Eagle Ford position, all while we maintained a strong balance sheet with conservative leverage, metrics and over $1.3 billion of available borrowing capacity under our current facility at year end. 
On our proved reserves, in addition to this strong operational and financial performance during the year, we also generated significant growth in the year end proved reserves, which increased 36% to over 4 point -- excuse me, 7.4 Tcfe. Cabot's all source finding and development cost for the year was $0.71 per Mcfe. This is particularly impressive given that over 43% of our 2014 capital was allocated to our oil properties in Eagle Ford that by nature are more capital intensive. Excluding the purchase of reserves in plays associated with our Eagle Ford acquisition last year, the total company finding and development cost was $0.65 per Mcfe. 
In the Marcellus, our all sources finding development cost was $0.43 per Mcf, highlighting the capital efficiency of our wells in the Northeast PA. Obviously, one of the components is that our wells in this area do deliver very strong EURs. The Cabot's average EUR for the 2014 program on proved developed wells was over 18 Bcf, up from the 16.9 Bcf for our '13 program. As a result of our continued performance improvements, we have also increased our reserve bookings on PUD locations in the Marcellus from an EUR of 10 Bcf to 11 Bcf per well. Our proved developed percentage increased from 59% in '13 to 61% in '14, highlighting our fairly conservative philosophy regarding our reserve bookings. For example, we booked a modest 0.7 offset PUD locations for each of our proved developed wells in the Marcellus at year end. 
Our year-end reserves were 60 -- excuse me, 96% natural gas, down from the 97% in '13, which was driven by 100% increase in our liquids reserve base. Approximately 89% of our proved reserves are located in the Marcellus shale. 
I would also like to highlight that the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection released the production data for the second half of 2014 this week. And once again, Cabot dominated the list with the top 16 wells in the stake. 
Now let's move to our '15 program. While our '14 operational financial performance are in the rearview mirror, the results do highlight Cabot's ability to deliver strong results in a challenged price environment. However, we are immune to the market conditions the entire industry is currently facing. On our third quarter earnings call in October of last year, I laid out the company's initial 2015 program, which was predicated on realized natural gas price and oil prices of $2.80 and $88, respectively. As you all are aware, the operating environment the industry is facing has changed drastically since our call less than 4 months ago. While much of the focus over the last few months has been on the declining oil price, we have also experienced a fairly meaningful decline in the natural gas prices, including the regional index prices in Appalachia, no different than what we are seeing in the major U.S. oil basins. Cabot and its peers have done an excellent job of finding an abundant supply of resources in the Marcellus. And as a result, supply-demand balance is currently at a synch. Until we see the rebalancing of the market, which reduced activity -- with the reduced activity, which I think is currently underway, I believe the industry will continue to see pricing pressures on both oil and gas. 
As you will recall, in the fourth quarter of last year we saw a significant increase in natural gas supply on the 3 major pipes in our area, which included a 15% sequential increase in Cabot's volume in anticipation of winter. However, winter demand did not materialize as we all would have expected. And as a result, we have seen the local interface in January and February set at levels significantly  lower than our initial forecast. 
In response to this lower commodity price environment, we have adjusted our 2015 program with a focus on protecting the balance sheet and maximizing our return on investment while still managing our growth profile. Despite the change in our absolute levels of activity in 2015, our strategy remains unchanged. A focus on aligning our capital spending to be primarily funded by operating cash flows, focus our drilling efforts on maintaining our acreage position and optimizing operating efficiencies and the retention of our high-quality employee base. This strategy has positioned us favorably leading into this commodity cycle. And we believe this strategy will allow us to exit the cycle extremely well positioned. 
Company updated capital budget for 2015 is $900 million, which is a 42% decrease compared to our initial budget. Approximately 80% of the program will be directed towards drilling and completion activity, with 60% allocated to the Marcellus and 40% allocated to the Eagle Ford. 
In the Marcellus, we are currently operating 5 rigs with plans to decrease to 3 rigs by the end of the second quarter. Based on this level of activity, we expect to drill approximately 70 net wells and place 65 to 70 wells on production during the year. Given the backlog of wells we carried into 2015 and our anticipated level of activity during the year, we expect to exit the year with approximately 45 wells in the queue for 2016. Despite drilling longer laterals in '15, we expect well cost average between $6 million and $6.5 million as a result of operating efficiencies and the service cost reductions that we have received to date. However, as we are all aware, this is a dynamic market and our expectation is that commodity prices remain depressed for a sustained period of time and the level of activity industry-wide continues to decline, we will likely see a further reduction in cost. 
In the Eagle Ford, we are currently operating 3 rigs with plans to decrease to 1 rig by the end of the second quarter. Given where oil prices are currently, our focus is solely on lease maintenance and meeting all drilling obligations. Based on our planned rig count for the year, we expect to drill approximately 45 net wells and place 40 to 45 wells on production during the year. Again, given our backlog of wells that we carried into '15, our anticipated level of activity during the year, we expect to exit '15 with approximately 20 wells teed up ready for 2016. Similar to the Marcellus, we expect well cost for the year to average between $6 million and $6.5 million with an opportunity for further cost reductions as we move through the year. 
We remain excited about what we have seen so far in our 90,000-acre net position, which is all contiguous. However, in light of the current price environment, we believe the prudent decision is to maintain all of the acreage and wait until a sustained recovery in prices before we start accelerating activities in the future. Based on this updated operating program, we have adjusted our production guidance range for the year to 10% to 18%, which includes 50% to 60% growth in liquids production. This guidance range assumes a modest level of curtailment to the Marcellus in anticipation of maintenance and high line pressures at certain points during the year. 
Additionally, we have also included a wedge of price-related curtailments in this guidance to account for those periods where price simply does not meet our threshold. Obviously, the natural question would be how much and what price we would take these actions. For competitive reasons, we will not disclose specifics but I will say that our production profile for the year assumes entire volumes in the first quarter with a reduction in the second and third quarters and increasing again in the fourth quarter. The realized commodity prices used in this updated budget to make our $900 million program were $0.45 per Mcf, $2.45 for our natural gas and $55 per barrel for oil. This includes the impact of our natural gas hedges, which covers about 28% of our natural gas volumes at the midpoint of our updated guidance range. 
Also for the full year, approximately 50% of our sales, gas sales, are priced at 3 major indices in Northeast PA, which is Tennessee, Leidy and Millennium. Under these assumptions, our operating program would result in a very small level of our spend, allowing us to maintain the same financial strength we demonstrated prior to this down cycle while still providing double-digit growth and generating returns. Some of you may find -- or may have questions about 2016, given our reduced level of activity this first year. First let me say that our internal model shows continued growth in 2016 with the level of growth dependent upon factors that will certainly be understand better as 2015 progresses. However, once you factor how the commodity price environment evolves throughout 2015, we do anticipate similar operational and supply reductions by other operators in Northeast PA in reaction to the current prices and our expectation is that this will ultimately result in a rationalization of the supply and demand dynamics in our area. 
Given the expectation for our tapering of supply growth, coupled with new takeaway capacities in the Northeast, that's Leidy Southeast expansion and the TICO Eastside expansion that's coming online in the second half of the year, we will remain flexible with our program if the market wants us to make changes. Given the productivity and the low capital intensity of our wells in the Marcellus, we are well-positioned to adjust our operations in short order. As a reminder, we grew to our current production levels by never operating more than 6 rigs in the Marcellus. And given the anticipated backlog of 65 wells company-wide at year end 2015, we do have plenty of optionality to accelerate completions in the second half of the year as we see fit. As I mentioned earlier, our plan is to maintain our high quality employee base and we believe that positions us very well in the light -- in the event of a quick recovery. 
Another key factor that will drive '16 growth and enhance program returns will be the anticipated in-service of Constitution Pipeline, which is currently planned for the second half of 2016. Cabot has 500 million a day of capacity on this pipeline. So the timing of when this pipeline comes online will obviously have an impact on 2016 production levels. As a quick update, on Constitution there were a few significant accomplishments at the end of last year that bear repeating. As you are aware, on December 2, 2014, the FERC issued a Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity, approving the Constitution Pipeline. In addition, on December 24, the New York DEC issued a formal notice of complete application regarding the final permits necessary from New York. We're currently awaiting the conclusion of the New York state public comment period, which is scheduled in on February 27, 2015. Moving forward, we are hopeful to receive our final permits from New York during the second quarter and immediately file for the implementation and construction plan with the FERC with construction beginning this summer. 
So in summary, I've covered many topics. We are well-positioned to adapt and succeed in this price environment. I think it's clear, our asset base and our disciplined focus lends itself to allowing us to generate returns at these price levels that maybe many other operators will not -- or may not experience. And despite the current market conditions, we remain committed to delivering our long-term shareholder value and certainly maintaining our strong balance sheet. Gary, with those comments, I'll turn it back over to you to queue up some questions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttextpreview: Dan, a couple of things, if I may. First of all, on Constitution. Just to be clear, so what has been -- what is the precise hold-off now then on moving forward with construction? I'd say -- I guess the right of way issue in New York is still the bottlenec
componenttext: Dan, a couple of things, if I may. First of all, on Constitution. Just to be clear, so what has been -- what is the precise hold-off now then on moving forward with construction? I'd say -- I guess the right of way issue in New York is still the bottleneck. But in terms of all the other preparations, can you actually start now? Or are you still waiting -- can you not probably start until everything is lined up? I'm just trying to understand what the bottlenecks might be.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question and a question that's obviously on a lot of people's mind. I'll make a brief comment and turn it over to Jeff for any specific color. But we have submitted all the permits. We submitted our original permits back in August of '13. There has b
componenttext: Good question and a question that's obviously on a lot of people's mind. I'll make a brief comment and turn it over to Jeff for any specific color. But we have submitted all the permits. We submitted our original permits back in August of '13. There has been significant dialogue between Williams, the operator of the pipeline, not only the FERC but also the New York DEC. The protocol in moving through this process is that the DEC has made the determination as I mentioned on the 24th of December that we have fulfilled our obligation to give them all of the information they need to deem the project complete. With that, though, there comes a public comment period. And that public comment period, we are in this period of time and it ends at the end of this month. Subsequent to that, the expectation is with no new issues that would have -- that have not come up over the last couple of years, that the New York DEC will grant a final permit. And then that will allow us to make the application to FERC to begin construction.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Doug, just to add a few points to that. The application process in New York and Pennsylvania for that matter and of course we're finished in Pennsylvania, has been pretty much what we expected, it's taking a little bit longer than we expected but the
componenttext: Yes. Doug, just to add a few points to that. The application process in New York and Pennsylvania for that matter and of course we're finished in Pennsylvania, has been pretty much what we expected, it's taking a little bit longer than we expected but the process is what it is and by getting the notice of complete application, it does signal that the New York DEC has all the information they need to issue the final permit. And the process we're in now is the standard and operating procedure, where public comments are welcome based on the action that New York DEC took. In terms of getting construction started, Williams will file an implementation plan with FERC, probably next month. And then an implementation plan will include permits from all the agencies involved, including the ones that FERC issued. And it will be complemented with the final permit from New York once that's issued. When FERC gives that final determination, they'll issue a notice to proceed with construction. At that point, construction can begin. So it allows moving pieces but you really cannot dig dirt until all the pieces are in place.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick follow-ups, I guess on some numbers, if I may. First, can you quantify the curtailments that you've assumed in your guidance for the current year? And finally, any scale of anticipated cost reduction from this point forward over and above wha
componenttext: Just 2 quick follow-ups, I guess on some numbers, if I may. First, can you quantify the curtailments that you've assumed in your guidance for the current year? And finally, any scale of anticipated cost reduction from this point forward over and above what you've already achieved in terms of service cost? And I'll leave there.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the curtailments, we will not be exactly specific. But I can say that if in fact all of the available production would move, we would certainly approach where -- the lower end of our previous guidance. And in regard to cost, again, we have seen t
componenttext: Okay. On the curtailments, we will not be exactly specific. But I can say that if in fact all of the available production would move, we would certainly approach where -- the lower end of our previous guidance. And in regard to cost, again, we have seen the cost roll off no different than the other operators that have made a release. And we anticipate though also, as you continue to see service or programs lay down rigs, there's going to be a natural tendency to continue to keep equipment and people teed up and busy through the service sector. And we can see additional service cost reductions throughout the year.

componenttext: And the only other one I have was just on the well cost reduction that you're seeing so far, what percentage of that is just your own optimization versus third-party service declines?
