componenttext: Okay, net will be high as well. Okay, got it. And then service cost. I guess what we've heard from other operators in Appalachia is that unlike some of the oil-producing basins, there wasn't really excess margins that service companies were generating last year. So the view is that given 2015 dynamics, they don't have that much room to give to where the types of cost deflation we're seeing from the oil basins 20%, 25% expected Q4-to-Q4 may not be realized. I think you did say the 25% is possible. But what would you say about that context provided by other Appalachian operators?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just make a statement about our own experience. And the -- each service provider can be a little bit unique on what their ultimate goal is. Some would prefer to capture margin and some would prefer to keep their equipment and their personnel
componenttext: Well, I would just make a statement about our own experience. And the -- each service provider can be a little bit unique on what their ultimate goal is. Some would prefer to capture margin and some would prefer to keep their equipment and their personnel busy and they would sacrifice margin. So our operation is a very consolidated acreage position. We have a very efficient operation from the standpoint of the service providers. And I'll talk about frac crews just as being the highest percentage of any one completed well besides the rigs. But we move from 1 location to the other and everything is set up and ready to go. So they keep their equipment and personnel running 24/7 and very efficient. And I think that is attractive to them. But you look at the reduction that we've referenced already. And we go from, say, a $7 million well to a $6 million to a $6.5 million well. We're already seeing those incremental reductions in service cost. And again, whatever the rest of the market does is -- and what service cost realizations they see is going to be all unique and individual. But we are seeing fairly significant service cost reductions.

componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful.  And can we just review again the trajectory of production for the year? So are you expecting production to be up in the first quarter? It sounds like it's going to be down the second, down in third. And then is it going to be a fair
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful.  And can we just review again the trajectory of production for the year? So are you expecting production to be up in the first quarter? It sounds like it's going to be down the second, down in third. And then is it going to be a fairly meaningful ramp in the fourth? And do you expect fourth quarter to be kind of flattish with 4Q '14? Can you just help us with that and break it up North versus South, if you could?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you summed it up on what our expectation is through the year. And we've given that 50% to 60% expected growth in the liquids for the year. Liquids production or the production profile in the South region is going to be more consistent than t
componenttext: Well, I think you summed it up on what our expectation is through the year. And we've given that 50% to 60% expected growth in the liquids for the year. Liquids production or the production profile in the South region is going to be more consistent than the production profile that we guided and put into our program in the North region. We just have -- we have more flexibility on swing volumes in the North region and on the Marcellus area than we do in the South region. So I guess at high-level summary, Joe, we kind of maintain and grow a little bit of our production year-over-year in the South region. And in the North region, higher first quarter, just like you grow through the year; the second, third quarter down and then increasing again in the fourth.

So it's not in our -- it's not in the cards right now. And the only way it's going to get into consideration would be having a difference in the price points from today.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question on the seasonality of production. Is there any reason that pattern wouldn't persist in future years, like '16 and '17 maybe it wouldn't be quite as dramatic? But is there any reason to think that wouldn't happen again with line pressures, et ce
componenttext: A question on the seasonality of production. Is there any reason that pattern wouldn't persist in future years, like '16 and '17 maybe it wouldn't be quite as dramatic? But is there any reason to think that wouldn't happen again with line pressures, et cetera?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, possibly a couple of reasons. One would be that we're restricted right now. And the reason why we have punitive differentials is because of the volumes of gas moving into the 3 pipes up there. In the future, we would expect in the pipes that Je
componenttext: Well, yes, possibly a couple of reasons. One would be that we're restricted right now. And the reason why we have punitive differentials is because of the volumes of gas moving into the 3 pipes up there. In the future, we would expect in the pipes that Jeff has been talking about that are on the drawing board and moving forward and have expected commissioning dates, with those pipes and allowing additional gas or gas to get out of that particular area and off of those 3 pipes in particular is going to allow, certainly, different dynamics going forward than we're experiencing today. Now, I can't predict exactly what the impact is going to be on supply side or the demand side, let's say, at the end of 2017. But I can say that you're going to have a significant level of additional volumes of our gas that would be seeking and priced in different markets than we're experiencing today. So operationally, Marshall, you can still have operational floors and pressures on pipes based on the amount of volume running through them. But I think the opportunity to -- and the flexibility that additional pipes is going to afford us in the future is going to be fairly significant.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So with Constitution coming on in the second half of next year, maybe there could be some seasonality between Q1 and Q2, but you wouldn't expect it once Constitution comes online?
componenttext: So with Constitution coming on in the second half of next year, maybe there could be some seasonality between Q1 and Q2, but you wouldn't expect it once Constitution comes online?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say you would probably see, since there's not the volumes of gas that have access to the air core system, I would say that you would probably, on those particular volumes, I would think that you probably would not see as much of the seaso
componenttext: Yes. And I would say you would probably see, since there's not the volumes of gas that have access to the air core system, I would say that you would probably, on those particular volumes, I would think that you probably would not see as much of the seasonality effects on that pipe as you -- as we experience today on the 3 pipes, Tennessee, the Leidy and the Millennium, with the volumes of gas that's trying to force their way into those pipes today.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions for me. On Constitution, I wanted to clarify to hopefully get a little bit more color on how you're thinking about those volumes in 2016 and beyond. Is the plan to potentially shift some of your existing production away from Leidy a
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions for me. On Constitution, I wanted to clarify to hopefully get a little bit more color on how you're thinking about those volumes in 2016 and beyond. Is the plan to potentially shift some of your existing production away from Leidy and Tennessee into that pipe and, therefore, improve margin? Or are you planning on completing new wells to grow production into 2016?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, both are really good questions. Both of them good questions. The indices, the price, received in the 3-pipe area that all of the operators are exposed to right now up in that 6-county area is going to be somewhat of a determining factor on whether or
componenttext: Yes, both are really good questions. Both of them good questions. The indices, the price, received in the 3-pipe area that all of the operators are exposed to right now up in that 6-county area is going to be somewhat of a determining factor on whether or not we relieve the amount of gas that is on those 3 pipes by just a flat cell transfer of 0.5 Bcf. Actually, it would be 650 million a day because Southwest is part of that Constitution Pipeline being a 650-million-a-day capacity. Or would it be incremental volumes that we flow into the pipe. And that decision, Matt, is going to be a combination of price point and the ability to diverse the amount of gas that is flowing into those of 3 pipes with some of the new pipes that are coming online, i.e., Leidy, Southeast, the impact on those 3 pipes, the TICO expansion and some of the other smaller projects that Jeff mentioned. So I can say this, though. But from a planning standpoint, we're going to be prepared to have incremental volumes going into the Constitution pipeline. But we're also going to remain focused on the best returns and price rationalization if the market has not done that for us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then my second follow-up, as you talked about previously, your Eagle Ford assets continue to improve in terms of the breakeven economics, given the enhanced completions you've put into place. Could you provide some color as to how you're thinki
componenttext: Great. And then my second follow-up, as you talked about previously, your Eagle Ford assets continue to improve in terms of the breakeven economics, given the enhanced completions you've put into place. Could you provide some color as to how you're thinking about potentially re-accelerating that program in the out years? And potentially, what commodity price you'd need to see at this point, given service cost to add rigs back to that market?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, our balanced focus, Matt, has been on  let's look at the amount of cash flow we're generating. And the amount of cash flow we generate is going to kind of dictate what we do with our capital program. So it would go hand-in-hand. We have a hig
componenttext: Well, again, our balanced focus, Matt, has been on  let's look at the amount of cash flow we're generating. And the amount of cash flow we generate is going to kind of dictate what we do with our capital program. So it would go hand-in-hand. We have a higher price point, better cash flow will roll into a consideration for adding rigs, whether it be in the Marcellus or the Eagle Ford. It is our objective, though, in the Eagle Ford to maintain all the acreage we have out there. We like what we're seeing. We like what the group is doing now. And we like the returns that we can get. But at $50, we're not impressed with the returns at $50. At $60, $65, certainly it has a return profile that starts getting attractive again.

componenttext: Bob, it's Scott Schroeder. As Dan alluded to, based on Holly's question in terms of the repurchase, clearly for 2015 the question you pose isn't on the table in light of how far we had to ratchet back our capital program, and we're still not quite exact equal with cash flow. But at the end of the day, we're balancing that decision in different times. We're looking at the disconnect between the underlying value we see in the shares and what the market at any one moment is giving for our shares in the marketplace. We've seen those disconnects over the last couple of years. And that's why between probably -- between '13 and '14 we bought in just under 10 million shares on that kind of dynamic.

componenttext: Thank you, Robert.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, Bob, some of the projects that are being proposed have actually -- gosh, probably in excess of 20 I have on my desk that we're interested in, some more than others, some that we have very good access to, some that may be more difficult to get to, and
componenttext: So, Bob, some of the projects that are being proposed have actually -- gosh, probably in excess of 20 I have on my desk that we're interested in, some more than others, some that we have very good access to, some that may be more difficult to get to, and I'm talking about transportation paths. But there's a lot of projects planned in the Atlantic -- Middle-Atlantic states. And in Pennsylvania, there's been a push to in conjunction with the ISO in that area to build some power generation and feed it with local supplies. So we're looking at projects that are close by Susquehanna County or have direct routes, pipeline routes, that we can reach these projects. I think the -- some of the planners of these, and we did mention the Panda project, they probably have 4 or 5 other projects that are well on the way in terms of planning locations and permitting and financing and so forth. But most of these guys are -- they get their power deal done first, in other words, access to the grid and then come to gas suppliers. And they have their wish list and we have our wish list and we try to work through those and come to terms. There's 4 or 5 power generators off the Iroquois system that we're working with as well. And there are some off the Tennessee system and there are some off the Leidy system. This is going to be a profit that goes on probably in the next 5 to 10 years even. Just a lot of opportunity for power generation with natural gas with coal retirements and with coal switching and oil switching. So it's a piece of the demand puzzle and it's very active and very dynamic. And where we're situated, in the Northeast corner, we're probably the closest supply to market there is. And so we're comfortable with these kinds of markets. And we'll be probably announcing, if we are successful, in the next year or 2 on some of these projects.

Just sort of thinking about the fact the DEC has never had to review a linear pipeline project of this magnitude the time it took them to issue the notice of completing application and attendance at the 3 public hearings?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I think at some point, Williams, I think they had their call yesterday -- they had, I think, they had some questions on this as well. But the way we understand the process and getting feedback from Williams on the progress, this is -- I'm not
componenttext: Okay. Well, I think at some point, Williams, I think they had their call yesterday -- they had, I think, they had some questions on this as well. But the way we understand the process and getting feedback from Williams on the progress, this is -- I'm not sure I agree with what you said about the magnitude of the project versus what DEC has seen in the past. There's lots of major pipelines through the state of New York, lots of gas pipeline, lots of power corridors, lots of water lines and so on and so forth. This is a relatively simple 124-mile pipeline through rural New York. It's got its environmental challenges, as all pipelines do. I think the New York DEC has run a very careful and thorough examination of the route and the issues and listening to the concerns of surface owners. And they're doing exactly what they should be doing. And at the end of the day, we hope to get a permit that lets this pipeline be built in the time frame that we've illustrated so far.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman,
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dan Dinges, Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ben, and good morning, all. Thank you for joining us today for the Cabot first quarter call. With me today, as usual, are several of our management team. Before we start, the standard regarding forward-looking statements do apply to my comments
componenttext:
Thank you, Ben, and good morning, all. Thank you for joining us today for the Cabot first quarter call. With me today, as usual, are several of our management team. Before we start, the standard regarding forward-looking statements do apply to my comments today. I would first like to touch upon a few financial and operating highlights from the first quarter that were outlined in this morning's press release. First -- excuse me, equivalent net production for the first quarter was slightly above 1.9 Bcfe per day, an increase of 43% over the prior year's comparable quarter and a sequential increase of 15% over the fourth quarter. Of particular note, our daily liquids production for the quarter increased 132% compared to the prior year's comparable quarter and 20% sequential -- sequentially over the fourth quarter, highlighting the success of our team in the Eagle Ford. 
Net income excluding select items for the quarter was $49 million or $0.12 per share and discretionary cash flow for the quarter was $240 million. Both of these items decreased relative to the first quarter of '14 due to a 34% decline in realized natural gas prices and a 55% decline in realized oil prices. 
On the coal side, our team continues to work hard and deliver on driving down unit cost, which is evidenced by the 10% decline in cash unit cost to $1.22 per Mcfe. I think that decline is even more impressive when considering that we have increased the percentage of all focused activity in our mix, which typically is more costly to operate on a per unit basis. 
Additionally, we reaffirm guidance, even with the planned curtailment, which is, I think, the right economic decision. In the Marcellus, our operational results for the quarter exceeded expectations. The company averaged over 2 Bcf per day of gross Marcellus production, which is 1.7 Bcf per day at net production, an increase, as mentioned previously, of 43% over last year's comparable quarter. We competed 19 wells and played 17 wells on oil production, which drove the 16% sequential growth for the quarter. These production levels highlight the productivity of our Marcellus assets and demonstrates that the asset quality and well performance are quite unique assets for Cabot. However, we would like to see more favorable natural gas prices, which we anticipate will materialize upon the in-service of several new takeaway projects in our area, scheduled over the next 12 to 18 months, along with the continued increase in natural gas demand growth. 
I want to also highlight that during the first quarter, the state of Pennsylvania began reporting monthly production data and did report for both January and February, Cabot was the top producer in Pennsylvania, which is not bad for a company that has never operated more than 6 rigs in a state. Marcellus pricing continues to be the primary focus of our conversations with shareholders and I imagine is front of mind for everybody on this call today. 
Our first quarter natural gas realizations were $2.46 per Mcf, which is $0.52 below the average NYMEX price for the quarter and improvement relative to the $1.04 differential in the fourth quarter. Excluding the impact of hedges, our realizations were $0.75 below NYMEX as compared to $1.21 in the fourth quarter of '14. Primary driver of the differential narrowing quarter-to-quarter was that our marketing team was able to secure a meaningful amount of favorable fixed-price contracts for the winter season, prior to the most recent decline in natural gas prices. Many of these deals do roll off in March. However, we do have over 20% of our expected volumes sold at a fixed priced above $2 in the second quarter. 
Based on our current view of where the regional will sell over the quarter, we anticipate that second quarter price realizations will be between $0.82 and $0.92 before NYMEX, below -- excuse me, below NYMEX and before the impact of hedges. Additionally, we anticipate another $0.40 to $0.45 uplift in realized prices from our hedges based on the current strip. So as we frequently get asked the question, we have provided a split of our pricing exposure by index on our website, which should provide some clarity on how we are marketing our gas for the quarter. We anticipate that the third quarter will look similar to the second quarter as it relates to the percentage of sales by index. 
As we have guided, we have reduced our production volumes for the second quarter, relative to the first quarter, in response to our expectation of continued weakness in pricing during the second quarter, some of which is being driven by numerous maintenance and construction projects directly related to our downstream market. Virtually, all of the pipelines are production riches have planned or scheduled projects during the second quarter, most notably is the new looping of the Transco lighting line, in conjunction with the Leidy Southeast expansion project. Although this expansion, 525 million cubic foot per day of new capacity, will ultimately be very beneficial to Cabot at in-service in December of this year, the 43-day construction period is expected to affect throughput on the Leidy Line currently in price -- currently resulting in pricing pressures during this period. We expect to produce between 1.55 and 1.6 Bcf per day of gross production in the Marcellus for the second quarter. And we'll continue to monitor the price environment before we make any decisions on selling more gas into the local market. It is clear from our first quarter production that we have the ability to move volumes in excess of these base load levels. But we are not going to chase production growth to the detriment of cash margins. As planned, we recently decreased our level of activity in the Marcellus to 3 rigs and 1 frac crew, down from 5 rigs and 2 frac crews at the beginning of the year. Our current operating plan and capital program assumes this level of operating activity remains constant for the balance of 2015. However, in light of our expectations for our continued weakness throughout Appalachia during the summer months, we do often reevaluate our program and may consider delaying completions as we await a more favorable price environment in the future, again, not anticipating affecting our guidance. 
In the Eagle Ford, moving onto the Eagle Ford. Our team had an outstanding quarter operationally in South Texas, as evidenced by the 19% sequential growth in daily liquid volumes over the last quarter. During the quarter, we placed 20 wells on production, many of which weren't current in line until late in the quarter, which resulted in the strong sequential production growth. As a reminder, much of this activity was driven by near-term held by production commitment, primarily from the acreage we acquired late last year. 
If we take a step back and we look at where our Eagle Ford program was a year ago, it really highlights the significant improvement we have seen from this asset in a short duration of time. On last year's first quarter call, we had just made a change in the management team overseeing the program and made the decision to increase our rig count from 2 to 3. The increase in the rig count was predicated on an increase in the return profile to over 50%, hoping as a result of well performance enhancements and decreased well cost. Keep in mind that we were running our economics at $90 per barrel at that point. We had approximately 600 gross locations identified based on 400-foot spacing. And frankly, we're pretty excited about the long-term value generation opportunity afforded us by these properties. If you fast forward 12 months and a lot of things have changed, the most obvious being the underlying commodity price. However, as a result of significant improvements in our operating efficiency and well performance, along with a reduction in service cost, our operation now eclipsed the same 50% rate of return of threshold at a price of $65 per barrel, which is only $5 higher than today's 12 months trip. Relative to the 600 gross locations we had mapped at this time last year, we have now increased that location count to over 1300 locations, as a result of our bolt-on acquisitions in the fourth quarter of last year and the success of our 300-foot down-spacing program across our acreage position. We have also seen a 30% decline in operating cost in South Texas, as our team continues to work on driving down our cost structure. We are currently running 2 rigs into play with plans to decrease to 1 rig by the end of May. Our plan is to remain at this level throughout year end. However, we will consider acceleration of completion activity in the Eagle Ford if we see a sustained oil price recovery or further reduction in drilling and completion cost, which have decreased to date, 20% to 30%. 
Now let's move to another area that has many questions in regard to our time with investors. On the year-end call, we discussed a few of the significant accomplishments. The Constitution has recently achieved, such as the FERC Certificate of Public Convenience, approving Constitution Pipeline and the New York DEC formal notice of complete application for the final New York permit. Also, we briefly discussed the regulatory process in New York requiring a public comment period extension, which closed on February 27, 2015. Today, we can continue that update with the following. The project remains on its current schedule for in-service during the second half of '16. The New York DEC is currently finalizing responses to the comments received during the public comment period. Constitution now has possession of 100% of all the tracks necessary to begin construction. Constitution is working towards the finalization of New York State permit by the end of the second quarter and FERC implementation plan is expected to be filed by Williams during the second quarter. 
Based on the progress during the last few months, we continue to be optimistic that construction can begin mid-summer, assuming all these permits are in hand. 
As we also mentioned in our press release, we recently amended our credit facility, increasing the total commitment from $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion, providing us ample flexibility in this challenged environment. Our lenders also approved an increase in our borrowing base from $3.1 billion to $3.4 billion, despite the lower commodity price environment. A total of 20 lenders participated in this facility, including 6 new banks. We are appreciative of the support we saw in this transaction. And we believe it demonstrates the quality of our company, both operationally and financially. 
Pro forma for this increase in commitment, we had over $1.5 billion of undrawn commitment as of the end of the first quarter. 
In this morning's press release, we initiated second quarter of production guidance, which implies slightly over 1.5 Bcfe per day of net equivalent production for the quarter, at the midpoint, despite the sequential decline in production relative to first quarter due to the previously mentioned curtailments in the Marcellus. We have reaffirmed our 2015 production growth guidance range between 10% to 18%, based on a stronger than anticipated first quarter and expectations for increase in production above second quarter levels later in the year. 
Our capital program for the current year remains unchanged at $900 million. I would have to highlight that not only that has our 2015 capital program weighted heavily to the first half of the year, the first quarter capital expenditures on the cash flow statement also reflect carryforward cash outlays associated with our capital incurred in '14 but not paid until this year. We have also decreased our unit cost guidance for LOE, taxes other than income and DD&A. These updates can be found on our website. 
In summary, our strong first quarter production highlights that Cabot is able to achieve operationally strong performance. Currently, lower natural gas prices are a reality through Appalachia. However, we are optimistic the environment improves over the next few quarters through a combination of decreased levels of operating activity, increased demand and new takeaway projects. Our goal is to protect margins and ensure we aren't giving away our valuable resources at marginal prices. Despite our planned reduction in volumes for the second quarter, we remain confident in our production guidance range for the year and continue to be excited about our mid-term outlook as we increase our portfolio of firm sales and firm transportation to close of 3 Bcf per day by the end of '17, of which approximately 70% reaches markets outside of Appalachia. 
With that, Dan, I'd be more than happy to answer any questions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Subash Chandra of Guggenheim.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was curious strategically if there's any interest at all in securing Southern Marcellus foothold. As I suspect, there's a shakeup coming in the American energy folks of the world, et cetera and if there's an interest in doing that. And then secondly, if
componenttext: I was curious strategically if there's any interest at all in securing Southern Marcellus foothold. As I suspect, there's a shakeup coming in the American energy folks of the world, et cetera and if there's an interest in doing that. And then secondly, if you can maybe get more granular on the impressive operating cost experienced in the first quarter?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. First, I'll respond to any M&A considerations within our company. We are -- we are proactive in evaluating opportunities out there each year. I think you are probably aware that we have our strategy session and certainly in environments as we in tod
componenttext: Okay. First, I'll respond to any M&A considerations within our company. We are -- we are proactive in evaluating opportunities out there each year. I think you are probably aware that we have our strategy session and certainly in environments as we in today. We have a time set aside in our Executive Board session, just as we did yesterday to talk about all the macro environment, including M&A opportunities, considerations. We are not in any discussions with a Southwest Marcellus or Utica opportunities down there. But we want to be aware of what opportunities are available and we'll continue to evaluate any possible opportunities. But specifically, for the Southwest part of the state, again, we're not in any transaction discussions or anything at this particular time. In regard to the operating side of the business, 2 of the guys here, Steven Lindeman, who is running our South region, and Phil Stalnaker running our North region, I'll let them comment on just some of the things that we've seen in the operating side of our business.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. For the South region in the first quarter, we really tackled our unit saltwater disposal cost. So that's one of the big drivers. And then, secondly, we switched out some of our trading chemicals and have driven that cost down. And we're still looking
componenttext: Yes. For the South region in the first quarter, we really tackled our unit saltwater disposal cost. So that's one of the big drivers. And then, secondly, we switched out some of our trading chemicals and have driven that cost down. And we're still looking at -- there are some things we're trying to tackle for the second half of the year in terms of electrification and other things that we can do to reduce our operating cost.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the North region, more of the same thing in the optimization looking out our recycling and our trucking cost and just kind of across the board working to lower cost.
componenttext: For the North region, more of the same thing in the optimization looking out our recycling and our trucking cost and just kind of across the board working to lower cost.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on the Eagle Ford. The electrification is I suspect that's for the artificial lift in this area. Do you see that happening in a timely fashion with getting land consent and that kind of stuff? And given a sense of what kind of op
componenttext: If I could just follow up on the Eagle Ford. The electrification is I suspect that's for the artificial lift in this area. Do you see that happening in a timely fashion with getting land consent and that kind of stuff? And given a sense of what kind of operating cost efficiencies you can have by maybe getting off diesel, which might be what's being used currently.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We've made a significant effort over the last half of the year and into the first quarter to get right away purchased. One of the main substations that we need for electrification was put in service in the first quarter. As a matter of fact, we are -
componenttext: Yes. We've made a significant effort over the last half of the year and into the first quarter to get right away purchased. One of the main substations that we need for electrification was put in service in the first quarter. As a matter of fact, we are -- some of our team is over there for an opening ceremony last night. And we are in the queue for several projects to get that online. And we're hoping to have a portion of field on power kind of into the third quarter of this year.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015

componenttext: Dan, just curious, if -- last quarter you alluded to this -- you guys communicated that you would have a high point in production in the first quarter and naturally with seasonal winter demand and taking of the firm sales contracts and then decline into 2Q and 3Q and rebound in the 4Q. Is the plan today with a reiterated guidance, are you guys more or less within the original plan that you set out a few months ago?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are. We could not predict exactly what the realizations were going to be. We thought they were going to be a little softer. We were glad to see quarter-over-quarter a little bit of reduction in the differentials. But our plan is still intact with
componenttext: Yes, we are. We could not predict exactly what the realizations were going to be. We thought they were going to be a little softer. We were glad to see quarter-over-quarter a little bit of reduction in the differentials. But our plan is still intact with our original guidance.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just for context and maybe you can go into little bit more how you're managing that curtailments. I know that there's downtime associated with project maintenance and construction. But just leveling sort of field volume pressures to build and nat
componenttext: And then just for context and maybe you can go into little bit more how you're managing that curtailments. I know that there's downtime associated with project maintenance and construction. But just leveling sort of field volume pressures to build and naturally curtailing volumes that way. And what sort of recovery in prices are we thinking about before you would start accelerating the volumes here?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are not going to go into specifics on the pricing for that decision process, David. But we do expect to see better realizations later in the year than we anticipated during this period, when the maintenance projects were going to be implemented [
componenttext: Well, we are not going to go into specifics on the pricing for that decision process, David. But we do expect to see better realizations later in the year than we anticipated during this period, when the maintenance projects were going to be implemented [indiscernible] in the shoulder months. In regard to our field operations and methodology of how we are reducing the volumes out there, we have discussed in the past that we have a very flexible gathering system that allows us to move gas even from 1 particular pad to multiple outlets. We do anticipate that as we raise the fuel pressures in the field and allow that to happen that we would naturally bring down some of the volumes that we would be moving into the pipe. And so it's not a shut in a particular portion of the field and produce the others at those volumes that they were at. It is more of across the board consideration on how we bring the field pressures up a little bit to allow the volumes to be reduced.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I could raise one more, perhaps with Jeff or anyone who wants to take it.  With Constitution potentially coming on in the summertime of '16, how are you guys thinking about the end markets there right now in terms of pricing? Is it -- I kno
componenttext: Got it. And if I could raise one more, perhaps with Jeff or anyone who wants to take it.  With Constitution potentially coming on in the summertime of '16, how are you guys thinking about the end markets there right now in terms of pricing? Is it -- I know that you would partially do it be better than Appalachia. But do you have a sense of how close that pricing should be to NYMEX and how you see that dynamic kind of building out?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, historic look, price points up there that right station and into that line are close to the NYMEX pricing. Various times of the year, it exceeds NYMEX pricing by a considerable margin. We already kind of broadcast that we will make that c
componenttext: Well, certainly, historic look, price points up there that right station and into that line are close to the NYMEX pricing. Various times of the year, it exceeds NYMEX pricing by a considerable margin. We already kind of broadcast that we will make that call on how we would roll into the Constitution volumes, whether it would be just total incremental volumes to what our current production is at that point in time of commissioning or phasing by displacing the volumes from our current price points to the Constitution pipeline. I think it's safe to say at that point in time, regardless of when Constitution is commissioned, whether it's in the middle of summer or right at the beginning of the third quarter, I think it is safe to say that those price points, more likely if they're consistent with historic, is going to be at a higher better price point than the current indices that we're selling into. So we would naturally move and fill 100% of Constitution immediately. But it may be just displacement from Millennium or Transco or Tennessee line.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I actually wanted to follow up that exact point, which is how you strategically determine the appropriate mix of filling Constitution with production you already have versus kind of new production. When do you have to make that call? Are you planning on i
componenttext: I actually wanted to follow up that exact point, which is how you strategically determine the appropriate mix of filling Constitution with production you already have versus kind of new production. When do you have to make that call? Are you planning on increasing your production capacity from where it is today by the full 500 million a day and then you make that -- you can make that call at the last second? Or is there a point where earlier on, where you have to figure out your rig count and make that call on the split between transferring production currently oversupplying or potentially oversupplying the local market versus new production to go into Constitution?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good question, Brian. And how I will answer the question will be dependent upon how much I make Phil Stalnaker squirm over here in front of me. But keep in mind that the capital intensity necessary for us to ramp up our volumes is minimal comparatively sp
componenttext: Good question, Brian. And how I will answer the question will be dependent upon how much I make Phil Stalnaker squirm over here in front of me. But keep in mind that the capital intensity necessary for us to ramp up our volumes is minimal comparatively speaking, when you look across the space to be able to find another 0.5 Bcf per day. The driving consideration for that volume of production is going to be not necessarily in the rig count, but it's going to be how we stage in frac crews to allow timely completions of those wells that we have in the queue. So the plan building up to that decision point, it would be our intent to have in the queue that will allow us to have that maximum flexibility is to have wells drilled and in the queue, waiting on completion, if you will, as opposed to backing up a step and saying that we haven't even drilled the wells or drilled those pad sites yet. So when you get towards the end of this year, the discussions that we'll have with the north will be, all right, let's look at our capital program, let's look at our cash flow, let's look at the dynamics of the macro market and let's make a call on bringing on another rig, if we felt like we needed it in the first quarter of '16. But also looking ahead at the end of the second quarter, beginning of the third quarter, how many frac crews do we want to have lined up to get ready to move those volumes in the Constitution. Again, keep in mind that Constitution is going to be filled immediately upon commissioning. The decision is going to be, do we backfill Tennessee, Transco, Millennium with those volumes and how long do we want to take to backfill those volumes. But at the end of this year, as we go into the planning stage for our initial budget for '16, which we present to the board in October, we'll have some of these discussions.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up is if you could just direct 2 other points. One, whether you're seeing any cost deflation that is unrelated to your activity levels, could push down your budget this year or not. And then your outlook for committing to additional substant
componenttext: And my follow-up is if you could just direct 2 other points. One, whether you're seeing any cost deflation that is unrelated to your activity levels, could push down your budget this year or not. And then your outlook for committing to additional substantive midstream takeaway arrangements.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why don't you cover the midstream? I'm going to have rollout.
componenttext: Why don't you cover the midstream? I'm going to have rollout.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, Brian. This is Jeff. I think there's a number of smaller projects that we're involved with Leidy Southeast this fall, being the very important project that we have some long-term sales associated with the pricing. There's, of course, following
componenttext: All right, Brian. This is Jeff. I think there's a number of smaller projects that we're involved with Leidy Southeast this fall, being the very important project that we have some long-term sales associated with the pricing. There's, of course, following up to that, there's the Colombia Eastside expansion. We have some additional capacity coming on at that point. After that, we have, of course, Constitution mid-summer of next year. And those will more or less short-term drivers of new capacity and Atlantic Sunrise in 2017 and also a new project for Tennessee. It's a smaller scale project of about 150,000 a day that once moved gas over into New Jersey or from production area. So that's the kind of short and longer-term projects.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Brian, on your question about cost, let me answer this and if I don't answer it fully, just let me know. But we do anticipate seeing additional incremental cost reductions in our operations. We have not realized any of the savings, as Steve indic
componenttext: Yes. And Brian, on your question about cost, let me answer this and if I don't answer it fully, just let me know. But we do anticipate seeing additional incremental cost reductions in our operations. We have not realized any of the savings, as Steve indicated, and say the electrification of some of our operations in Eagle Ford. But we also think that the service providers are also obtaining and getting additional cost concessions from their providers that would naturally be shared somehow with the operators. So we do anticipate that additional cost reductions would grow through our program between now and year end.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, there have been many reports in the press about frac log [ph] or significant backlog but not completed wells. And previously, Q1 earnings, you said that Cabot should exit 2015 with approximately 45 wells in the Q4 [ph] 2016 in the Marcellus and appro
componenttext: Dan, there have been many reports in the press about frac log [ph] or significant backlog but not completed wells. And previously, Q1 earnings, you said that Cabot should exit 2015 with approximately 45 wells in the Q4 [ph] 2016 in the Marcellus and approximately 20 wells in the Eagle Ford. And now you have talked about this a little bit in the Q&A and some prepared remarks. But I want to see if that's still the case. And if so, how do these figures compare to the number of wells if you had queued up entering this year? And then, if you have any big picture thoughts regarding this industry for log is it real? Is it real, is it overstated or whatnot? I'd love to get that color as well.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, our expectations for year-end '15, we do still maintain our expectations of 20 wells in Eagle Ford and 45 wells or so in the Marcellus. That is going to remain consistent. I don't see much getting into way of that expectation. In regar
componenttext: Well, first of all, our expectations for year-end '15, we do still maintain our expectations of 20 wells in Eagle Ford and 45 wells or so in the Marcellus. That is going to remain consistent. I don't see much getting into way of that expectation. In regard to frac log and looking at the backlog, it always seems to be a moving number that you see out there. And I see different counts what is backlog at any one given time. I do know that from an operational standpoint and I'll talk more geographically about, say, where it could have a larger impact in our Northeast Pennsylvania area, in that 6-county area. If you look at that area, we've talked in the past about how many rigs are running and how many frac crews are up there. Our most recent intelligence is that you had through, say, January, February, March, a certain number of rigs running up there. And most recently, in April, we placed a number of rigs up there in that particular area and only 12 rigs that are currently running. And we have at any given times 6 to 8 frac crews operating in that neck of the woods. Now if you do the simple math and you look at the 8 Bcf or so a day that's kind of coming from that area, 12 rigs and 6 or 8 frac crews are going to have one hell of a time keeping up with any natural decline that you might suspect from the volumes that are being produced. Now I do think that there were and have been just we like had some curtailed volumes that could keep maybe backfilling some of that gas volume. And you're maybe today not seeing any type of real inflection point. But it doesn't take a mental to do the quick numbers on IPs and 30-day averages and all that for those number of pieces of equipment to say that there has to be some depletion of the backlog, if you will. And the ability of wells to keep up with the natural depletion that would occur in -- under those circumstances. So on '14, at the end of '14, I think we had a similar number. We might actually have a couple more wells at the end of '15 as we had at the end of '14. But for the most part, we're going to have a similar backlog for us.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: That color is very helpful. And then my follow-up is some oil service providers have highlighted the tremendous opportunity in refracting wells. Can you see the same opportunity for Cabot? And if so, in what region?
componenttext: That color is very helpful. And then my follow-up is some oil service providers have highlighted the tremendous opportunity in refracting wells. Can you see the same opportunity for Cabot? And if so, in what region?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I've had just a recent discussion with Phil in regard to our Eagle Ford operation, just the industry in general on kind of what's being done out there. And then, kind of in a high level, I'll let him just talk about maybe some of the areas that a re
componenttext: Well, I've had just a recent discussion with Phil in regard to our Eagle Ford operation, just the industry in general on kind of what's being done out there. And then, kind of in a high level, I'll let him just talk about maybe some of the areas that a refrac might be considered. Steve?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Pierce, when we look at that the successful refracs throughout the industry, really what has been targeted is wells that have had, I would say, less sand concentration or lower connectivity pump as compared to what the current standard would be. And th
componenttext: So Pierce, when we look at that the successful refracs throughout the industry, really what has been targeted is wells that have had, I would say, less sand concentration or lower connectivity pump as compared to what the current standard would be. And then, secondly, a group of wells that might have different proof of clustering than what's being used. So a lot of people are targeting wells that might have been, let's say, proliferated at 100-foot spacing and now people are targeting 50-foot spacing and the same thing kind of on a sand basis, where people may have done 800 pounds per foot versus now with people pumping close towards 1600 pounds per foot. Cabot does have some opportunity for refracs. I would say that we would target those when we do the downspaced wells and do those in conjunction with that, so you could get the full benefit of the zipper frac, both on the re-frac and on the new well that you drill and the downspaced perspective.

componenttext: No, That's not the understanding we have from Williams at this time. The DEC has taken the time to thoroughly review the comments that were submitted in the public comment period. Our understanding that they are close to releasing the answers, so to speak, on these comments. There are still some work in progress surrounding the permits. But we made a lot of progress here in the last couple months. And our expectation that those permits will be issued sometime in the second quarter, May, June time period.

componenttext: Absolutely. So from the comments that have been submitted, our understanding from Williams is that the comments are very similar in nature, that the comments were submitted to FERC. And so there's been nothing in their review of the comments, has been substantially different, I guess, than what they have seen before. So we're encouraged by that so far.

And that period I believe took from February of '04 to October -- February of '14 to October of '14, like 8 months. And we want the same time that the have on studying this. That's the concern I have. Should I have that concern that they can [indiscernible]

componenttext: I think the application for the permit has been in New York DEC's hands for much longer period of time than what you're referring to. I also think that they've had a very lengthy time to review.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Beard of Iberia.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Beard of Iberia.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I apologize if this question has been asked but I've had some trouble getting on the call. But I just wanted to review you seem to have more volatile production here in the first quarter, second quarter and prices being fairly weak, I would have expected
componenttext: I apologize if this question has been asked but I've had some trouble getting on the call. But I just wanted to review you seem to have more volatile production here in the first quarter, second quarter and prices being fairly weak, I would have expected volumes to be commensurately lower. Can you just talk a little bit about the price volume relationship? And I know we're talking fairly short-term point of view and maybe what to expect going forward relative to that price volume relationship?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we made an early determination. And based on our crystal ball, which again is no better than anybody else's. But with our crystal ball, we made and placed our guidance out there early on that did take into consideration curtailed volumes. And where
componenttext: Well, we made an early determination. And based on our crystal ball, which again is no better than anybody else's. But with our crystal ball, we made and placed our guidance out there early on that did take into consideration curtailed volumes. And where we are right now, our first quarter volumes were more robust. And we felt good about our operational performance in the first quarter. But in the second quarter, we had an anticipation again of the maintenance projects and all particularly affecting the pipes that we sell into up in the Marcellus, we thought that by the continued supply increase and the construction projects and maintenance projects up there that we would see softness in prices at this period of time. I think that is holding true. We're backing off some of the volumes. And we think, just from a prudency standpoint, to protect shareholder assets and not to compromise our margin to the extent that the current price would yield, we think it is prudent in this environment to take some of the gas and protect our margins. I think that's a prudent economic decision on our part. And we are going to stick to that.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just a follow-up. Given that we've seen some reduced rigs operating in the Marcellus, both east and west. Do you think there'll be an impact relative to production from the curtailment in the second half of the year? Or is it like
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just a follow-up. Given that we've seen some reduced rigs operating in the Marcellus, both east and west. Do you think there'll be an impact relative to production from the curtailment in the second half of the year? Or is it likely to be pushed off into next year for the industry?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think by the second half of the year, whether or not you see a rollover is debatable. I think you will see a possible inflection point in any of the growth profile. The -- again, back to just the numbers that are out in front of us, if you believe up in
componenttext: I think by the second half of the year, whether or not you see a rollover is debatable. I think you will see a possible inflection point in any of the growth profile. The -- again, back to just the numbers that are out in front of us, if you believe up in that 6-county area, that there is in April, beginning in April, there were 12 rigs running and 6 to 8 frac crews in that area and producing approximately 8 Bcf a day. Even if all of those wells were to the degree and to the performance levels of Cabot type wells, you are going to have a difficult time being able to maintain, much less grow the production volumes from that production base. So I think the numbers have reflected that the other wells that are drilled out there are not like Cabot wells. And so therefore, we would be inclined to believe that at some point in time, you're going to see an inflection point on the volumes produced.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Daniel Guffey of Stifel.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys continue generating results in the Eagle Ford, especially compared to earlier vintage wells. I guess, could you give details surrounding your current standard completions on and any kind of improvements you're currently testing to enhance product
componenttext: You guys continue generating results in the Eagle Ford, especially compared to earlier vintage wells. I guess, could you give details surrounding your current standard completions on and any kind of improvements you're currently testing to enhance productivity?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we will get granular on it, but -- and I'll let Steve answer some of this. But our lateral lengths are beyond 6000 feet. And our proppant per lateral foot is 1600 or so right now. And we are certainly aware that some companies have gone up to 2300,
componenttext: Well, we will get granular on it, but -- and I'll let Steve answer some of this. But our lateral lengths are beyond 6000 feet. And our proppant per lateral foot is 1600 or so right now. And we are certainly aware that some companies have gone up to 2300, 2400, maybe 2500 pounds per lateral foot. And our South region we'll explore with some of that. As we continue our operation, we've got our down-spacing program that we feel comfortable with and have a number of pilot programs that has given us the confidence that a 300-foot downspace is going to be useful and how we place our wells. From this point forward, as we have been successful in maintaining our primary term acreage and we have had responsive land owners negotiate with us in regard to the timing of the [indiscernible] wells or continuous development wells out there on their properties. Some of those mineral owners do not want to produce their oil into a low price environment. So we've been able to extend some time on those particular leases. So between now and end of the year, with 1 rig and not a 24/7 frac crew, some of the experimentation, if you will and completion efforts that we would be implementing are not going to be very numerous because we've been kind of a somewhat of a holding pattern with 1 rig and 1 crew.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: You kind of touched on the 300-foot space in your prepared remarks and just now. I'm curious, how many pilots do you have in the 300-foot spacing? Is that kind of standard completion and how are you looking at it? Is it staggered or are you just waiting k
componenttext: You kind of touched on the 300-foot space in your prepared remarks and just now. I'm curious, how many pilots do you have in the 300-foot spacing? Is that kind of standard completion and how are you looking at it? Is it staggered or are you just waiting kind of in the lower zone and keeping 300-foot apart?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we are in the lower zone with our 300-foot spacing. But we have several points within the lower zone that we are landing our wells. And we have 20 or 30 of the pilots that are out there that have shown good results. But again, we have not gotten to
componenttext: Well, we are in the lower zone with our 300-foot spacing. But we have several points within the lower zone that we are landing our wells. And we have 20 or 30 of the pilots that are out there that have shown good results. But again, we have not gotten to a point of doing anything yet in the upper Eagle Ford on the staggers that some have been talking about. Our staggers are in a narrower range within the lower Eagle Ford on our placements. But we've also had 300-foot spaced laterals that have been in the same landing points also within the lower Eagle Ford that we feel comfortable about.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then you touched on M&A previously but curious if you guys are interested in seeing any bolt on acquisition opportunities in South Texas?
componenttext: And then you touched on M&A previously but curious if you guys are interested in seeing any bolt on acquisition opportunities in South Texas?

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, not get granular on it, we look at all the opportunities that are available out there. We are just fresh off of picking up 2 properties that were good fits to our operation in the Eagle Ford that we closed in the fourth quarter. The results t
componenttext: Well, again, not get granular on it, we look at all the opportunities that are available out there. We are just fresh off of picking up 2 properties that were good fits to our operation in the Eagle Ford that we closed in the fourth quarter. The results that we have seen from that efforts proved out an efficient program and consistency with our expectations or exceeding expectations with the wells that we drilled on those properties. So it all comes together and you can get into an environment that is a little bit more robust in a $50 oil price and if it makes sense, we'll do it.

headline: Cabot Oil & Gas Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Dan. I appreciate everybody's focus on Cabot. As you're well aware and we are well aware, we are in a challenge commodity price environment, both oil and gas, efficiencies are being realized and cost reductions realized throughout our operation, bot
componenttext: Okay, Dan. I appreciate everybody's focus on Cabot. As you're well aware and we are well aware, we are in a challenge commodity price environment, both oil and gas, efficiencies are being realized and cost reductions realized throughout our operation, both on a cash cost basis for our unit production, but also in our capital program. And we expect to see continued improvement throughout the year. Now thanks, again for your interest in Cabot.
